metadata.title: Facile preparation and enhanced photoelectrical performance of Sb2Se3 nano-rods by magnetron sputtering deposition

Facile preparation and enhanced photoelectrical performance of Sb2Se3 nano-rods by magnetron sputtering deposition
Guang-Xing Lianga,b, Xiang-Hua Zhanga,b,⁎, Hong-Li Mab, Ju-Guang Hua, Bo Fana, Zhong-Kuan Luoc,⁎, Zhuang-Hao Zhenga, Jing-Ting Luoa, Ping Fana,⁎
a Institute of Thin Film Physics and Applications, College of Physics and Energy, Shenzhen University, 518060 Shenzhen, China b Laboratory of Glasses and Ceramics, Institute of Chemical Science UMR CNRS 6226, University of Rennes 1, 35042 Rennes, France c College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenzhen University, 518060 Shenzhen, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Sb2Se3 Nano-rods Sputtering Chalcogenide
A B S T R A C T
In this work, a simple and effective method for fabricating Sb2Se3 nano-rods films by magnetron sputtering Sb2Se3 alloy target at a substrate temperature of 375 °C is proposed. The thermally induced regular shape and vertically arrayed nano-rods exhibits a well-crystallized structure with a preferred crystallographic orientation of (221) and a stable valence of Sb3+ and Se 2−. The obtained thin film has a band-gap of 1.32 eV and a high absorption coefficient of 105 cm−1 in visible region. The photo-electrochemical measurements show that the Sb2Se3 nano-rods are p-type semiconductors with an excellent photo-response. A photovoltaic solar cell using the Sb2Se3 nano-rods film as absorber has demonstrated and a clear photovoltaic effect with an encouraging power conversion efficiency of 2.11% can be achieved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
One-dimensional (1D) semiconductor nanostructures (nano-wires, nano-tubes, nano-belts and nano-rods) have attracted considerable interest for various electronic and optoelectronic applications due to their remarkable electronic, optical, catalytic and mechanical properties arising from the small dimensions which distinctly differ from bulk nano-structures. These 1D nano-materials may eventually lead to next generation electronic, photonics, sensors and energy applications [1,2]. Antimony triselenide, a new non-toxic and earth abundant material, has been extensively explored for many applications including photovoltaic solar cells, thermoelectric device and electrochemical hydrogen storage and lithium ion battery devices [3]. Sb2Se3 exhibits a direct band-gap of 1.1–1.3 eV, which approaches the ideal Shockey-Queisser value and has the ability to extend efficient light harvesting with an absorption coefficient of 105 cm−1 over the near-IR region up to approximately 1000 nm [4]. In addition, Sb2Se3 compound with an orthorhombic structure has an inherent anisotropic crystal structure, which is the most appropriate structure for the abnormal 1D nano-structure semiconductors [5]. The Sb-Se binary system has only one stable phase (Sb2Se3), which is different from the Cu-Se and Sn-Se binary system. During the past decades, considerable efforts have been devoted to the synthesis of 1D Sb2Se3 nanostructures including nano-rods, nano-wires, nano-tubes and nano-ribbons by various techniques such as hydrothermal, solvolthermal routes in non-vacuum environment [6–8]. The main drawback was time-consuming and more importantly, the
inevitable incorporation of impurities coming from solvent or oxides. Recently, Cho H. K [5] reported an interesting method for preparing 1D Sb2Se3 by evaporating an excess of Se on the electron-deposited Sb/Se precursor which is then annealed. High photoelectric of the obtained thin films has been reported. Up to now, little attention has been paid to the preparation of vertically arrayed 1D Sb2Se3 based on vacuum sputtering method. This technique has however several advantages such as excellent composition transfer of the target material, good uniformity and widely available equipment required for the film deposition.
In this paper, we report an effective sputtering route to grow uniform, well-crystallized, regular shape and vertically arrayed Sb2Se3 nano-rods at appropriate depositing temperature. This technique minimizes the risk of impurity introduction which is inherent to the non-vacuum and avoids excess consumption de Se in the thermal evaporation process. The structural, morphology, optical and electrical properties of the amorphous and annealed Sb2Se3 nano-rods thin films were discussed and based on which the performance of photochemical cell and solar cell were also revealed.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental details
sections.text:
Sb2Se3 films were deposited by in-situ radio-frequency magnetron sputtering process with a homemade sputtering system of 2-in. magnetron sputtering gun and a rotatable substrate holder with heating system. Prior to deposition, the blank or Mo coating glass

substrates were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone and alcohol for 10 min respectively. Single polycrystalline target consisting of Sb2Se3 (40:60 at%) was used as the sputtering source. The vacuum chamber was evacuated to a background pressure of 6.0×10−4 Pa. High purity (99.99%) Ar was introduced at the rate of 40 sccm and the deposition was carried out at a working pressure of 0.5 Pa after a pre-sputtering for about 10 min to remove contaminants from target surface. The amorphous film was prepared at room temperature with a sputtering time of 20 min and the nano-rods thin film were prepared with a deposition duration of 45 min and a substrate temperature around 375 °C. All the sputtering power was fixed at 30 W. Thus, the thicknesses of amorphous and the nano-rods film were kept at about 450 nm. The prepared Sb2Se3 nano-rods film was used as an absorber to prepare solar cells with a total effective area of 0.09 cm2 with the following structure SLG/Mo/ Sb2Se3/CdS/ZnO/AZO. A 150 nm thick CdS buffer layer was deposited by chemical bath deposition at 85 °C. An 100 nm thick intrinsic-ZnO and a 800 nm thick conductive-ZnO:Al films were prepared in sequence by using RF magnetron sputtering at room temperature as window layers. Metallic contact was painted with Ag colloids. Note that no metal grid and anti-reflection coating was deposited on the thin film solar cells.
The crystal orientation and the structure of the films were determined by X-Ray diffraction (XRD) (Ultima-iv) with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA from 10 to 60°. The crystallinity of the Sb2Se3 phase was confirmed from Raman spectra obtained by using a Renishaw inVia Raman spectrometer with an Ar+ laser as excitation source (514.5 nm). The chemical valence was obtained by using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) with a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source of 1486.6 eV. The surface morphology of the films was analyzed by a SUPRA 55 scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and the composition was obtained by energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDS) associated to the SEM (Model: BRUKER QUANTAX 200). The film thickness was measured using DEKTAK XT profilometer and the SEM cross-sectional measurement. The transmittance spectra of the samples were conducted using a LAMBDA 950 UV/VIS/NIR spectrophotometer in a wavelength range of 300–2500 nm at room temperature. The relationship between the band-gap and the optical absorption has been found to fit the Tauc relation defined as,αhυ C hυ E= ( − )g 1/2, here, α was absorption coefficient, C a constant, υ the photon frequency and h the plank constant. The photo-electrochemical (PEC) characterization of the film was carried out in 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution as electrolyte, where the film, a high-purity graphite plate and a SCE were used as the working, counter and reference electrodes, respectively. A 300 W xenon lamp was used as the light source with the light intensity kept at 40 mW/cm2. The Current density–voltage (J-V) curves of the solar cells were measured using a source meter (Keithley, 2400 Series) under AM 1.5 G light illumination from a 3 A solar simulator with intensity calibrated to 100 mW/cm2 by using a Si reference cell. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) spectra were measured using a power source (Zolix SCS101) with a monochromator and a source meter (Keithley 2400).

sections.heading: 3.1. Composition and morphology
sections.text:
With the different sputtering conditions for obtaining the amorphous and nano-rods Sb2Se3 film, the thin film composition, collected in Table 1, changes significantly as expected. Concerning the amorphous Sb2Se3, it can be found that the ratio of Sb/Se approached the stoichiometric composition of 0.66, indicating a quite good composition transfer to form the film by sputtering a Sb2Se3 target. However, with the condition optimized for obtaining Sb2Se3 nano-rods films, important loss of Se is observed, probably due to the relatively high substrate temperature of 375 °C, leading to partial Se sublimation. A gray-black-wish colour is observed and the nano-rods films exhibit a
good adhesion to the substrate with no visible mechanical defects, such as cracks or peel-off. To examine the composition throughout the nanorods films, Fig. 1(a) shows exclusively the characteristic peaks of Sb and Se elements. The mapping of these two elements is shown in Fig. 1(b, c and d), showing uniform composition over the interrogated area. The surface and cross-sectional morphology of the amorphous and Sb2Se3 nano-rods film was observed by SEM and shown in Fig. 2. The similar thickness of the amorphous and Sb2Se3 nano-rods film is about 450 nm with the above-mentioned profilometer results. No distinct grains Sb2Se3 pertained to amorphous films can be observed. However, as can be seen from the low-magnification SEM image of Sb2Se3 nano-rods films, a large amount of nano-rods is randomly distributed on the film surface. The high-magnification SEM image reveals that the nano-rods films are consisted of the regular shape and vertically arrayed nano-rods with a length of about 0.5–1 µm and a width of about 0.12–0.20 µm, comparable to those prepared by evaporating excess Se with the required thickness of more than 5 µm [5]. A better understanding of the exact growth mechanism for these highly uniform, well-crystallized, regular shape and vertically arrayed Sb2Se3 nano-rods by sputtering method is still in progress.

sections.heading: 3.2. Crystal structural properties
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of Sb2Se3 amorphous and nano-rods films. No distinct Sb2Se3 phase can be detected in the amorphous film, except the broad peak indicating the formation of amorphous Sb2Se3 due to a low mobility of atoms and high quenching rate with a substrate at room temperature. However, a large amount of nano-rods are effectively prepared at the substrate temperature of 375 °C during our sputtering process. All the diffraction peaks are indexed to the orthorhombic Sb2Se3 with the space group of Pnma 62 (JCPDS Card No. 15-0861). And no peak attributable to the detrimental Se in Sb2O3 phases can be observed thanks to the vacuum deposition technique. In addition, the intense and sharp diffraction peaks suggests the nanorods are well-crystallized with the preferred crystallographic orientation of (221). There are two weak diffraction peaks related to the predicted Sb, according to the composition analysis, detected at around 30° and 40°, indicating the increase of Sb content conformed to the composition analysis. Thus, the controllable in-situ heating-system in our sputtering facilities was proven to be a key factor for preparing nano-rods films. The thermal energy enhanced the mobility, facilitating the self-organization of Sb2Se3 nano-rods with a well-defined structure and a high crystallinity.
The structure of the Sb2Se3 films has been further analyzed by Raman scattering and the spectra are shown in Fig. 4. For the amorphous films, the broad peak around 188 cm−1 is associated to the amorphous nature of Sb-Se with possibly a negligible amount of crystalline Sb2Se3 phases, due to the fact quenching and the low mobility of Sb and Se atoms with a substrate at room temperature. As for the Sb2Se3 nano-rods films, it exhibits a narrow peak at 188 cm −1 [4] and greater peak intensity, indicating the enhancement of crystallinity during the sputtering process at the substrate temperature of 375 °C.
To investigate the constituent element oxidation state of the Sb2Se3 amorphous and nano-rods films, the XPS study was carried out. Fig. 5 represents the binding energies obtained from the high resolution core level spectra regions of Sb and Se. Binding energies (BE) of all the peaks were corrected using C1s energy at 284.6 eV in addition to the
charge compensation by the flood gun associated with the spectrometer. The expected oxidation states of Sb3+ and Se2− in all Sb2Se3 film
prove the purity of Sb2Se3 phase and the nano-rods exhibits much more stable valence state than amorphous. The spin orbit coupled doublets of Sb3d core levels was split into 3d5/2 (528.41 eV) and 3d3/2 (537.93 eV) with the separation of 3d doublet by 9.52 eV attributed to the charge state of Sb3+. The Se3d core levels 3d5/2, 3d3/2 appeared at 52.77 and at 53.65 eV with a doublet separation of 0.88 eV, in good agreement with the Se in metal selenide [9].

sections.heading: 3.3. Optical and electrical properties
sections.text:
The sharp absorption edge in Fig. 6 inferred that the band gap was due to the intrinsic transition of the Sb2Se3 films but not due to other impurities. The band gap values, obtained by extrapolating the straight point where α=0, are 1.32 and 1.78 eV for nano-rods and amorphous film, respectively. The well-crystallized Sb2Se3 nano-rods show excellent optical property with an absorption coefficient of 105 cm−1 in visible light and a band gap value Eg =1.32 eV, close to the value of single crystal Sb2Se3 [10], suggesting its efficient absorption of the sunlight. This type of materials should be highly efficient for photo catalysis and for photovoltaic solar cell applications.
In order to evaluate the photo-electrochemical (PEC) performance of Sb2Se3 films, photocurrent density versus potential was measured under chopped light. The big difference in the PEC performance of
amorphous and nano-rods Sb2Se3 film is shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7(a) shows that the nano-rods Sb2Se3 film is identified as p-type semiconductors, due to their photocurrent density increase with a negative bias. An excellent photocurrent of about 4.5 mA/cm2 at near 1.0 V has been obtained with in addition a better rectification [4] for the higher degree of crystallinity. To evaluate the stability of the photocurrent, a chronoamperometry measurement has been performed and the result is shown in Fig. 7(b). After 1000 s of the photo-electrochemical experiment, the photocurrent is stabilized almost at its original level, demonstrating its potential to validly prevent photo-corrosion under long irradiation [11]. In addition, the response and recovery time is another important parameter for evaluating the speed of the ON/OFF switching. As shown in the inset of Fig. 7(b), The response time of 1.5 s and the recovery time of 1.8 s obtained for this material are better compared to other reported materials [4,11] And they remain almost the same over 40 cycles, demonstrating the stability of our prepared Sb2Se3 nano-rods device. As it is known, well-crystallized Sb2Se3 nanorods lead to the defects reduction and the photocurrent rapidly reaches a steady state both on rise and decay stages [12]. Moreover, as to nanorods, the depletion space charge layer forms due to the surface state and Fermi-level pinning, allowing the physical separation of the electron and hole [13]. As the critical diameter of nano-rods is reached, the depletion layer remains fully depleted and the recombination barrier increases and may further increase the photocurrent. Thus, the high photo-electrochemical property of Sb2Se3 nano-rods can also be attributed to the larger Sb2Se3 nano-rods of about 120–200 nm prepared by the sputtering method [8,13].
Photovoltaic solar cells based on Sb2Se3 nano-rods film with a prototype structure of Mo/Sb2Se3 nano-rods/CdS/ZnO/AZO were prepared. Fig. 8 shows that the J-V characteristics for the Sb2Se3 solar
cell demonstrate a clear photovoltaic effect with power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 2.11% under AM 1.5 G light illumination. Compared to the reported highest efficiency of 4.60% with the pure Sb2Se3 solar cell having a planar structure prepared by thermal evaporation [14] and 3.21% with Sb2Se3 sensitized cell of mesoporous structure prepared by spin-coating method [15], we show a higher Voc of 420 mV, compared to the reported 353 and 305 mV, but lower Jac of 12.21 mA/cm2, compared to the reported 24.4 and 22.3 mA/cm2 and lower fill factor of 41.0%, compared to 50.1% and 47.2%. Using the sputtered nano-rods as absorber in solar cell, the well-crystallized and the porous structure of the nano-rods may give larger specific surface leading to increasing absorption over the surface. In addition, when the incident light arrives with a certain angle, light trapping can happen due to the multiple refraction. However, the EQE of the device is shown in the inset of Fig. 8 and the EQE value was lower than 60% over the whole visible region. The calculated Jac from the EQE spectra is 12.97 mA/cm2 which is comparable to our experiment vaule. For the moment, the main challenge is to obtain adequate CdS, ZnO and AZO films covering the nano-rods surface to form the hetero-junction. The lower Jac and fill factor in our prototype solar cell is predictable. Moreover, the Se loss in Sb2Se3 nano-rods film during the sputtering on the heated substrate increase the selenium vacancy (VSe), which can increase the recombination loss and reduce the device performance.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The Sb2Se3 nano-rods films have been effectively prepared with a simple method by sputtering Sb2Se3 alloy target with the substrate temperature of 375 °C. The thermally induced nano-rods with regular shape and vertically arrayed structure exhibit a length of about 0.5– 1 µm and width of about 0.12–0.20 µm. The Sb2Se3 nano-rods films show well-crystallized structure with a preferred crystallographic orientation of (221) and a stable valence of Sb3+ and Se 2-. No peak attributable to the detrimental Se in Sb2O3 phases can be observed thanks to the vacuum sputtering method. A band-gap calculated from the transmittance spectra is 1.32 eV with an absorption coefficient of 105 cm−1 in visible light, which is very good for photo-electronic application. PEC measurements show that the Sb2Se3 nano-rods are p-type semiconductors with an excellent photo response. Its resistance towards photo-corrosion under long irradiation is attributed to the high degree of crystallinity and the large nano-size. Using the sputtered Sb2Se3 nano-rods as absorber to fabricate a solar cell, a clear photovoltaic effect with PCE of 2.11% has been obtained for the first time. This preliminary result demonstrates the highly interesting potential of using Sb2Se3 nano-rods films as absorber for photovoltaic applications. Further work is necessary and is in progress in order to better understand the exact growth mechanism of the highly uniform, well-
crystallized, regular shape and vertically arrayed Sb2Se3 nano-rods by sputtering method.
